FacilityName: Golden Valley Grape Juice & Wine, LLC

_prev_prog_2.Description: Golden Valley Grape Juice & Wine, LLC is committed to protecting the safety and well-being of our employees, as well as the environment.  We've undertaken studies to determine where our hazards might potentially exist, and the preventive steps we've taken to ensure they remain in the "potential" category.  Our employees receive regular training, and all of our operators are certified.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:



Golden Valley Grape Juice & Wine, LLC is committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by its accidental release prevention program that includes management practices in areas such as operating procedures, equipment maintenance, hazard analysis and employee training associated with the processes at our facility. 



It is the policy of Golden Valley Grape Juice & Wine, LLC to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.





2.    The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled:



The facility's primary activity is the preparation of both grape juice and wine.  There is one regulated substance present at this facility that is subject to California Accidental Release Program/Risk Management Plan regulations, anhydrous ammonia.  Anhydrous ammonia is used as a refrigerant in the cold storage refrigeration equipment.





3.    The Worst Case Release Scenario(s) and the Alternative Release Scenario(s), including administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distances for each reported scenario:



To perform the required offsite consequence analysis, the EPA's RMP *Comp(TM) and 2000 US Census data for LandView 5 were used.  The following paragraphs provide details of the chosen scenarios.



The worst case:

The worst case release scenario involves a catastrophic release from the receiver tank.  In this scenario 2891 lbs. of Ammonia is released.  Ammonia liquefied under pressure is released to a pool with total vaporization assumed within 10 minutes.  No passive mitigation systems such as a building enclosure were taken into account to calculate this scenario.  A rural setting was used in RMP Comp.  The regulatory required atmospheric conditions were used: Class F atmospheric stability and 1.5 meters/second wind speed to a toxic endpoint of 0.14 mg/L.  



The maximum distance to the toxic endpoin

t is 1.0 miles. 



Alternative Scenarios to Off Site



To calculate a release rate that would show offsite consequence, alternative release scenarios involves the release of ammonia liquid from a compressor seal at 100-pounds-per-minute that is assumed to be controlled in 30 minutes.  At class D atmospheric stability and 3.0 meters/second wind speed, the toxic endpoint of 0.14 mg/L of ammonia, the endpoint reaches 0.3 miles.  According to the Landview Census 2000 Population estimator, there are sixteen persons with the potential for an offsite release in this scenario



Alternative Most Likely Scenario



The alternative release scenario involves the release of 600 lbs. of ammonia vapor from a damaged valve that is assumed to be controlled in 30 minutes at a release rate of 200 lbs per minute.  No passive mitigation controls such as a building enclosure have been taken into account to calculate the scenario and the release is assumed to be controlled by the manual shutdown of the system.  At class D atmospheric stability and 3.0 meters/second wind speed, the maximum distance to the toxic endpoint of 0.14 mg/L of ammonia is 0.2 miles.  There is a total of twelve persons potentially affected by this scenario.

4.    The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:



Golden Valley Grape Juice & Wine, LLC has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the California Accidental Release Prevention Program requirements set out under CCR Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at our cold storage facility.



Safety Information:



Golden Valley Grape Juice & Wine, LLC maintains a detailed record of safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes.



Process Hazard Review:



Golden Valley Grape Juice & Wine, LLC has conducted a hazard review to ens

ure that hazards associated with the processes are identified and controlled.  The refrigeration system is a new commercial unit.  Ammonia refrigeration plants are very different from complex chemical processing operations.  Many of the operations in chemical processing are not found in refrigeration plants.  There are no chemical reactions.  Moreover, ammonia refrigeration is a mature industry.  While there are new developments leading to more efficient operations, the design principles are fully available.  A complete understanding of the safe design and operating envelope is available to design practitioners in the industry.  Hazard reviews can result in findings or recommendations for improvements to prevent potential releases.  The management system includes that these findings or recommendations are promptly brought to resolution.  



The study will be re-evaluated at a regular interval of every five years or whenever major changes in the process are proposed.  Any findings related to the hazard analysis will be addressed in a timely manner.  



The most recent review of hazards was performed on October 18, 2006.



Operating Procedures:



For the purposes of safely conducting activities within the covered processes, Golden Valley Grape Juice & Wine, LLC maintains written operating procedures.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround.  The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.



Training:



Golden Valley Grape Juice & Wine, LLC has a training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating the refrigeration system process are competent in the operating procedures associated with the process.  Refresher training is provided at least annually and more frequently as needed.



Maintenance Program:



Golden Valley Grape J

uice & Wine, LLC carries out routine maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes among others; pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps. The most recent review/revision of maintenance procedures was performed on October 18, 2006.  Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices.  Furthermore, these personnel are offered specialized training as needed.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.



Compliance Audits:



Compliance audits provide a means by which the management of a plant assures itself that employees are properly carrying out their duties for preventing accidental releases.  



Golden Valley Grape Juice & Wine, LLC has conducted an audit for this CalARP submission to determine whether the provisions set out under the CalARP rule are being implemented.  



This compliance audit was conducted on October 18, 2006.  



Additional audits will be carried out at least every 3 years and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits will be undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.





Incident Investigation:



Golden Valley Grape Juice & Wine, LLC will promptly investigate any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  Such investigations will be undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring.  All reports of incidents will be retained for a minimum of 5 years.



5.    Five-year Accident History:



There have been no releases from this facility.



6.    Emergency Response Plan:



Golden Valley Grape Juice & Wine, LLC carries a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.

The plan includes evacuation procedures and location, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public.



To ensure proper functioning, emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced.  The plan is regularly reviewed and updated to reflect any changes that affect the plan
